moves.1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. exd5: The french exchange varation is considered inferior to the normal e5.
moves.3... exd5 4. Be3 Bd6 5. Nd2: This is the modern way of developing the knight in these types of opennings. The idea behind it is that Nd2 allows white to retain the option of c4.
moves.5... Ne7 6. Ngf3 Nf5: this move exploits the fact that my bishop has no good retreat squares.
moves.7. Bd3: by playing Bd3 I hope to use the E pawn after ...Nxe3 to support a future attack against d5.
moves.7... Nxe3: This creates a target for black to pick on.
moves.8. fxe3 f5: limiting the scope of the bishop.
moves.9. c4: with my pawn structure already in a mess I play with a sense of haste to gain some advantage before black can finish the job on the e file.
moves.9... dxc4 10. Bxc4: This prevents black from castling to safety.
moves.10... Qe7 11. Qe2: defending e3 and increasing my influence over e4.
moves.11... Be6: I do not think this is a wise move by black to offer the exchange of the light bishops. With the light bishops of the board I am able to increase my influence over e4 with greater ease.
moves.12. Bxe6 Qxe6 13. O-O Nc6 14. a3: This prevents any funny business on the queenside via Nb5, or Bb5.
moves.14... O-O 15. Qd3 Ne7 16. Rae1: I now have managed to gain the upper hand in the fight for e4.
moves.16... Kh8 17. e4: This is a clearing move that opens up lines of attack.
moves.17... fxe4 18. Rxe4 Qd5 19. Rh4: Provoking a weakness. I fully except my opponent to see this.
moves.19... Qf5: My opponent wants to play without queens, but I have a nasty suprise.
moves.20. Ne4: The mating net is beginning to take form on h7. Suddenly black is the one is trouble.
moves.20... Ng6 21. Rxh7+: I beautiful move that leads to mate.
moves.21... Kg8: Black can not take the rook because of Nfg4 winning the queen.
moves.22. Qc4+: You can run but you can't hide.
moves.22... Qf7 23. Nf6+: and black resign after he sees that he will suffer massive carnage.
